page.title: 08The Lydford Churches
page.content: The church of St Peter,West Lydford originated in the 12th century but was rebuilt in 1844 by Rector W. Hungerford Colston. Standing in an idyllic setting beside a weir on the river Brue it has two fine stained glass windows,a beautifully carved wooden eagle lectern and a clean and cared for look.The 15th century font is all that remains of the old church. Less often used is St Mary's, East Lydford,built on a new site in 1866 after the original 14th Century church beside the river was constantly being flooded.Ruined gravestones mark the spot.The carved wooden pulpit and Norman font were brought from the old church and an unusual alabaster plaque on the West wall shows St George fighting the dragon.
